The Mission

Data-driven research is vital for modern decision-making, yet it often presents significant privacy risks when handling individual information. Differential Privacy (DP) has emerged as the gold standard for addressing these risks, providing a mathematically rigorous framework to protect privacy while maintaining statistical utility.

This internship focuses on contributing to the OpenDP Library—a high-profile collaboration between Harvard University and the global research community. The library is built in Rust for safety and performance, with a Python ecosystem designed for data scientists worldwide.

Key Focus Areas

1. Privacy Auditing Frameworks

You will adapt and integrate novel auditing frameworks to empirically measure privacy leakage. This involves benchmarking existing mechanisms against theoretical bounds to ensure real-world implementations match their mathematical guarantees.

2. Research & Theoretical Contributions
  • Advanced Composition: Implement adaptive concurrent composition for zCDP and Rényi Differential Privacy.
  • Hypothesis Testing: Develop DP-compliant statistics for difference of means and independence tests.
  • Benchmarking: Explore utility trade-offs for regression models and confidence intervals.
3. Engineering & Ecosystem Integration
  • Mechanism Design: Implement truncated noise and interval exponential mechanisms.
  • Polars Integration: Help bridge the gap between OpenDP and the Polars DataFrame library for high-performance data processing.
  • New Frontiers: Investigate graph-based domains and continual observation mechanisms.

Who You Are

  • A student in Computer Science, Mathematics, or Statistics.
  • Proficient in Python. Knowledge of Rust is a significant advantage.
  • Excited by the intersection of rigorous mathematical proofs and high-quality software engineering.
  • Prior exposure to Differential Privacy is a strong plus, but an eagerness to learn is essential.

Ready to contribute?
